Key Arguments: The legislation is viewed as draconian and akin to censorship laws found in dictatorships.
The government should not have the power to determine what constitutes misinformation.
The legislation could lead to self-censorship and stifle free speech.
The government has previously pressured social media companies to remove content, indicating potential misuse of the new powers.
The laws could be used to silence political opposition, such as critics of the Voice referendum.
The legislation is seen as contradictory and undemocratic, with unelected officials making decisions on acceptable speech.
A bill of rights is suggested as a better alternative to protect freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: Just the idea that a government or Commonwealth agency should have the right to determine what is misinformation and what is not and have the power to compel its citizens to remove said 'misinformation' is frightening.
This is undemocratic overreach on steroids.
If liberty means anything at all it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear.
